ul.li: The intercepts of a line are the points where the graph crosses the axes.
The intercepts of a graph often represent the starting or ending values for a particular variable.

li.p: To find the x-intercept of a graph:
Substitute 0 for y in the equation and solve for x.
To find the y-intercept of a graph:
Substitute 0 for x in the equation and solve for y.

assemblage.title: To Graph a Linear Equation Using the Intercept Method

Find a third point on the graph as a check. (Choose any convenient value for x and solve for y.)

ul.li: A ratio is a type of quotient that allows us to compare two numerical quantities.

assemblage.title: Ratio
assemblage.p: The ratio of a to b is written \dfrac{a}{b}.

ul.li: A rate is a ratio that compares two quantities with different units.
A proportion is a statement that two ratios are equal. In other words, a proportion is a type of equation in which both sides are ratios.
We use cross-multiplying to solve proportions.
Two variables are said to be proportional if their ratios are always the same.
The slope of a line measures the rate of change of y with respect to x.

assemblage.title: Slope

ul.li: Lines have constant slope. No matter what two points on a line we use to calculate its slope, we always get the same result.
The slope of a horizontal line is zero, and the slope of a vertical line is undefined.

assemblage.title: Slope-Intercept Form
assemblage.p: A linear equation written in the form y=mx+b is said to be in slope-intercept form. The coefficient m is the slope of the graph, andb is the y-intercept.

ul.li: The constant term in the slope-intercept form tells us the initial value of y, and the coefficient of x tells us the rate of change of y with respect to x.

assemblage.title: To Graph a Line Using the Slope-Intercept Method

ol.li: Write the equation in the form y=mx+b.
Write the slope as a fraction, m = \dfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}.
Use the slope to find a second point on the graph: Starting at the y-intercept, move {\Delta y} units in the y-direction, then {\Delta x} units in the x-direction.
Find a third point by moving {-\Delta y} units in the y-direction, then {-\Delta x} units in the x-direction, starting from the y-intercept.
Draw a line through the three plotted points.

li.p: Two lines are parallel if their slopes are equal, that is, if m_1 = m_2 or if both lines are vertical.
Two lines are perpendicular if the product of their slopes is -1, that is, if m_1 m_2 = -1 or if one of the lines is horizontal and one is vertical.
The equation of the horizontal line passing through (0,b) is \blert{y=b}
The equation of the vertical line passing through (a,0) is \blert{x=a}

assemblage.title: Two-Point Formula for Slope
assemblage.p: The slope of the line joining points P_1(x_1,y_1) and P_2(x_2,y_2) is \blert{m=\dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}}~~~~~~\text{if}~~~~x_2 \not= x_1
